questions.question: Which of these options is not valid in this sentence?: ‘You _____ speak loudly in a library.’

choices.answer: Mustn’t
Don’t have to
Can’t
Aren’t allowed to

questions.question: Why is this sentence wrong ?: 'She didn’t need to have dressed up but she did so.’

choices.answer: Because you can’t use past simple.
Because you need an ‘s’ in ‘need’.
Because the right one is: She needn’t have dressed up.
Because this is lack of necessity.

questions.question: What’s the difference between ‘You mustn’t speak French’ and ‘You don’t have to speak French’?

choices.answer: The 1st one is prohibition and the 2nd one obligation.
The 1st one is strong advice and the 2nd one weak advice.
The 1st one is lack of obligation and the 2nd possibility.
The 1st one is prohibition and the 2nd  lack of obligation.

questions.question: What would be the best answer to this question?: ‘May I call you by your first name?’

choices.answer: It’s Rachel.
I don’t know.
Yes, of course.
I am Mrs. Smith.

questions.question: Which of these options doesn’t mean the same as: ‘I regret not applying for that job’?

choices.answer: I should have applied for that job.
I wish I had applied for that job.
It’s a pity I didn’t apply for that job.
I would like to apply for that job.

questions.question: Whenever we use ‘may’ we can also use ‘might’, is that true?

choices.answer: Yes,always.
Yes, except for the case in which we express permission.
False.
None of the others.

questions.question: Which of the following sentences is grammatically right?

choices.answer: They ought to organise a better plan.
They should to organise a better plan.
They must to organise a better plan.
They’d better organised a better plan.

questions.question: Which of these options means the same as: ‘I’m sure you weren’t at home yesterday’?

choices.answer: You mustn’t have been at home yesterday.
You didn’t have to be at home yesterday.
You can’t have been at home yesterday.
You might have been at home yesterday.

questions.question: Which of these options IS NOT a piece of advice?

choices.answer: You might talk to her.
You ought to talk to her.
You had better talk to her.
You should talk to her.

questions.question: Why is the following sentence ungrammatical?: ‘Hopefully, we will can visit you tomorrow.’

choices.answer: Because it doesn’t express possibility.
Because we can’t express ‘ability’ in the future.
Because you can’t use two modal verbs together.
Because you need “would” instead of “will”.
